name: Datong
title: Datong - Traveling China like your home yard
overview: Datong, located in northern Shanxi Province near the border with Inner Mongolia, stands as one of China's most remarkable repositories of Buddhist art and architecture. This city of 3 million people served as the capital of the Northern Wei Dynasty during the 5th and 6th centuries, a pivotal period when Buddhism flourished and spread throughout China. The legacy of this golden age remains visible in the extraordinary monuments that have made Datong a UNESCO World Heritage destination and a pilgrimage site for art historians, religious scholars, and travelers from around the world. The Yungang Grottoes represent Datong's crowning glory—a series of 252 caves and niches containing over 51,000 Buddhist statues carved into the sandstone cliffs. Created between 460 and 525 AD, these sculptures range from tiny figures barely an inch tall to colossal Buddhas standing 17 meters high. The artistry displayed here represents the fusion of Indian Gandharan styles with Chinese aesthetic traditions, creating a unique visual language that would influence Buddhist art throughout East Asia. The sheer scale and artistic sophistication of Yungang make it one of the three great Buddhist cave temple sites of China, alongside Dunhuang and Longmen. Equally impressive is the Hanging Temple (Xuankong Si), perched precariously 75 meters high on a sheer cliff face about 65 kilometers from Datong. This architectural marvel, built over 1,500 years ago, defies gravity with its wooden structures supported by thin stilts and rock-hewn beams. Remarkably, the temple is dedicated to three religions—Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism—with statues of all three traditions sharing the same sacred space. Datong itself has undergone extensive renovation of its ancient city wall and traditional neighborhoods, creating a pleasing historic atmosphere that complements its world-class archaeological treasures. The city's cuisine reflects its northern location with hearty wheat-based dishes, most notably the famous Datong knife-cut noodles, shaved directly from a block of dough into boiling water for a uniquely chewy texture.

highlights.cuisine: Datong Knife-cut Noodles (Dao Xiao Mian), Braised Lamb (Hong Shao Yang Rou), Shanxi Vinegar dishes, You Mian (oat noodles)
highlights.bestTime: Spring (April-May) and Autumn (September-October) with mild weather
